node.title: 'They stop women from having dreams': Arezo is speaking out, something forbidden in her homeland
node.alt: A woman leans against a stone wall.
node.description: Exam pressure in Year 12 can be hard enough, but Hobart student Arezo Hami has had the added layer of negotiating help for Afghan family members coping with life under the Taliban.
node.content:
["Arezo Hami has just finished grade 12 exams, but navigating Australian bureaucracy to help her family and friends back in Afghanistan has proved to be the bigger challenge.", "It is just over\u00a0100 days since the Taliban took control of Afghanistan, and the 18-year-old Hobart student and Hazara woman\u00a0has spoken out about the impact it has had on the local Afghan community.", "\"Everyone was really sad and really scared because they have family in Afghanistan and they are all trying to get them out,\" she told Ryk Goddard on ABC Radio Hobart.", "\"For the generation now who don't know anything about the Taliban, everyone was just seeing their families scared and it was devastating.\"", "", "
Arezo addresses the crowd at the Reclaim the Night rally in Hobart.(Supplied: Anna Bateman)
", "Arezo hasn't lived in Afghanistan \u2014\u00a0she was born in Iran and came to Australia as a refugee, and has lived in Tasmania since 2015.", "She can see the past trauma in her parents' eyes.", "\"I understand how my parents feel, they tell their stories about how the Taliban took over 20 years ago and how they are back now,\" she said.", "\"Everyone in the community was just so sad, it affected everyone.\"", "On Thursday night she spoke about her experiences at Hobart's Reclaim the Night event which highlights\u00a0the plight of women from various cross-sections of the community, including those living with a disability and Aboriginal women.", "", "
Hazara woman Arezo Hami wants to give Afghan women a voice.(Supplied: Arezo Hami)
", "
Giving a voice
", "Arezo has been busy studying for her final exams at Elizabeth College while trying to help members of the Afghan community navigate Australia's complex immigration system.", "\"There are families here who don't know how to speak or write\u00a0English, and their children had to fill out forms or go and ask for help from someone else,\" she said.", "\"I was dealing with study to prepare for exams but then I had to fill out forms for so many families.", "\"The chances of them getting accepted was like 1 per cent.\"", "Arezo knows there isn't much she can do from Tasmania, but she is trying to give a voice to those in her homeland.\u00a0", "\"I'm trying to advocate for my people,\" she said.", "", "
Women took to the streets in Kabul in the days day after the Taliban takeover but there\u00a0are now reports of women activists being killed.\u00a0(AP)
", "Communication with family in Afghanistan has been difficult due to a lack of internet and when her uncle died recently getting\u00a0information was challenging.", "\"The only thing we can do from here is hope that\u00a0Australia accepts more refugees from Afghanistan,\" she said.", "\"We can pray for them to live another day, they are starving, they are hiding from the Taliban and running away.", "", "
Arezo has been helping family and friends in Afghanistan seek asylum.(ABC News: Maren Preuss)
", "
Police force dreams
", "Arezo wants to be a police officer, a dream she has held since she was a young girl.", "\"If I could join the police here it would be the greatest thing ever,\" she said.", "\"In Iran I didn't see a lot of women police officers and I really wanted to be one.", "\"In my family there are no women who are police and I want to be the first one.\"", "", "
Arezo wears a hijab and says the Hobart community is very accepting of it.(Supplied: Arezo Hami)
", "She knows it's something that would not happen under Taliban rule, and is grateful to be living in Australia.", "\"I would have not have gone to school and done exams and followed my dreams.\u00a0They force women and children to marry their militants.", "\"Here it's so different, right now I'm speaking out and in Afghanistan the women are not allowed to do that.\"", "Arezo wears a hijab and said she was initially scared in Australia.", "\"When I first came here I was a bit scared and thought people might attack [me],\" she said.", "\"I don't wear full coverage \u2026\u00a0my mum used to wear it when she came here and I was so scared for her and watching out for her.", "\"But now it's fine, no one judges you and everyone understands, it's really great in Hobart.\""]
